title: Fundamentals of Programming
description: Test your knowledge of programming basics
subject: Computer Science

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT a programming paradigm?
questions.explanation: Descriptive Programming is not a standard programming paradigm. The main paradigms include Procedural, Object-Oriented, Functional, and Logic Programming.

questions.text: What does the acronym 'API' stand for?
questions.explanation: API stands for Application Programming Interface. It defines the ways different software components should interact.

questions.text: Which data structure operates on a Last-In-First-Out (LIFO) principle?
questions.explanation: A Stack follows the Last-In-First-Out (LIFO) principle, where the last element added is the first one to be removed.

questions.text: What is the time complexity of binary search on a sorted array?
questions.explanation: Binary search has a time complexity of O(log n) because it divides the search interval in half with each step.

questions.text: Which of the following is an example of a high-level programming language?
questions.explanation: Python is a high-level programming language. Assembly and Machine Code are low-level languages, and Microcode is even lower level, directly controlling processor operations.

title: Calculus Concepts
description: Test your understanding of basic calculus principles
subject: Mathematics

questions.text: What is the derivative of e^x?
questions.explanation: The function e^x is its own derivative, making it a unique and important function in calculus.

questions.text: What is the integral of 1/x?
questions.explanation: The integral of 1/x is ln|x| + C, where C is the constant of integration.

questions.text: Which of the following represents the chain rule for differentiation?
questions.explanation: The chain rule states that the derivative of a composite function is the derivative of the outer function evaluated at the inner function, multiplied by the derivative of the inner function.

questions.text: What is the limit of sin(x)/x as x approaches 0?
questions.explanation: The limit of sin(x)/x as x approaches 0 is 1. This is a fundamental limit in calculus and can be proven using the squeeze theorem.

questions.text: What is the second derivative of position with respect to time?
questions.explanation: The second derivative of position with respect to time is acceleration. The first derivative gives velocity.

title: Classical Mechanics
description: Test your knowledge of Newton's laws and applications
subject: Physics

questions.text: What is Newton's First Law of Motion?
options: For every action, there is an equal and opposite reaction
An object at rest stays at rest, and an object in motion stays in motion unless acted upon by a net force
Energy cannot be created or destroyed, only transformed
questions.correct_answer: An object at rest stays at rest, and an object in motion stays in motion unless acted upon by a net force
questions.explanation: Newton's First Law, also known as the Law of Inertia, states that an object will maintain its state of rest or uniform motion in a straight line unless acted upon by an external force.

questions.text: What is the SI unit of force?
questions.explanation: The SI unit of force is the Newton (N), which is defined as the force needed to accelerate a 1kg mass at 1 m/s².

questions.text: Which of the following is a vector quantity?
questions.explanation: Velocity is a vector quantity because it has both magnitude (speed) and direction. Time, mass, and energy are scalar quantities.

questions.text: What is the law of conservation of momentum?
options: The total momentum of an isolated system remains constant
The total energy of an isolated system remains constant
The total force in an isolated system remains constant
The total mass in an isolated system remains constant
questions.correct_answer: The total momentum of an isolated system remains constant
questions.explanation: The law of conservation of momentum states that the total momentum of an isolated system (where no external forces act) remains constant over time.

questions.text: What happens to the gravitational force between two objects when the distance between them is doubled?
questions.explanation: According to Newton's Law of Universal Gravitation, the gravitational force is inversely proportional to the square of the distance. So if the distance doubles, the force becomes (1/2)² = 1/4 of its original value.

title: Cell Biology Essentials
description: Test your knowledge of cellular structures and functions
subject: Biology

questions.text: Which organelle is known as the 'powerhouse of the cell'?
questions.explanation: Mitochondria are known as the 'powerhouse of the cell' because they generate most of the cell's supply of adenosine triphosphate (ATP), the energy currency of the cell.

questions.text: What is the primary function of chloroplasts in plant cells?
questions.explanation: Chloroplasts contain chlorophyll and are responsible for photosynthesis, the process by which plants convert light energy into chemical energy.

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT a component of the cell membrane?
questions.explanation: The cell membrane is composed mainly of a phospholipid bilayer with embedded proteins and cholesterol. DNA is primarily found in the nucleus and mitochondria.

questions.text: What is the process by which cells engulf particles or fluids?
questions.explanation: Endocytosis is the process by which cells engulf external particles or fluids by forming vesicles from the cell membrane. Exocytosis is the opposite process.

questions.text: Which cell organelle is responsible for protein synthesis?
questions.explanation: Ribosomes are responsible for protein synthesis. They can be found free in the cytoplasm or attached to the endoplasmic reticulum.

title: Chemical Reactions and Equations
description: Test your understanding of chemical reaction types and balancing equations
subject: Chemistry

questions.text: What type of reaction is: 2H₂ + O₂ → 2H₂O?
questions.explanation: This is a synthesis or combination reaction where two or more substances combine to form a single product.

questions.text: In the reaction: C₃H₈ + 5O₂ → 3CO₂ + 4H₂O, what is being oxidized?
questions.explanation: In this combustion reaction, the carbon in C₃H₈ is oxidized from -8/3 to +4, and hydrogen is oxidized from +1 to +1 (in H₂O). Both elements in propane are being oxidized.

questions.text: What is the balanced equation for the reaction between aluminum and copper(II) sulfate?
questions.explanation: This is a single displacement reaction where aluminum replaces copper in copper(II) sulfate. The balanced equation accounts for the charges of Al³⁺ and Cu²⁺.

questions.text: Which of the following is an endothermic reaction?
options: Neutralization of an acid with a base
questions.explanation: Photosynthesis is an endothermic reaction because it absorbs energy from sunlight. The other reactions listed are exothermic, releasing energy.

questions.text: What is the pH of a 0.01 M HCl solution?
questions.explanation: The pH of an acidic solution is calculated as -log[H⁺]. For a 0.01 M HCl solution, pH = -log(0.01) = -log(10⁻²) = 2.
